Emergency admissions and escalation within (ED) ...................................................... 7
Introduction

Admission to hospital may sometimes be necessary as part of a person's treatment and recovery to facilitate their care and provide a safe environment. This can be a stressful experience for the person involved, their family or carers and every effort is made to ensure that the admission is supportive and aimed towards recovery and that the person's privacy and dignity is maintained throughout.

The purpose of this policy is to provide a clear framework for staff on the procedures for arranging inpatient admissions, setting out clear guidance in situations where there is a shortage of available beds within local services. The general principles of effective bed management and Trust policy are set out in this document for all patients needing admission. Supplementary guidance and protocols are detailed in appendices.
The underlying principle of this policy is that all patients requiring urgent admission to hospital will be found a bed in the service.
Scope

This policy is aimed at all staff within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust'), but particularly those directly involved in the management of the admission of patients into the hospital.
Definitions

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
Quality and Safety Committee

Transfer incidents will be reported via the Trust's incident reporting process (Datix). These will be investigated in line with Trust Policy and where appropriate reports submitted to the Quality and Safety Committee. Complaints will be dealt with under the Trust complaints process and where appropriate submitted to the operational risk management committee.
Critical Care Network
Critical Care Transfers will be audited internally and delayed transfers from critical care will be reported to the Clinical Governance Committee on a monthly basis.
Managing Director:

As the Trust's Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for ensuring MSE has robust complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Medical Director:
The Medical Director has overall responsibility for ensuring MSE has a safe clinical bed management pathway.
Consultant Physicians / Surgeons:

Review new patients daily, and document an expected date of discharge (EDD's) in the notes within 12 hours of admission. They will also highlight any patients that are safe for transfer from the specialty ward, by documenting in the medical notes and requesting patients be identified as ‘category 6' patients on the TeleTracking system.

To support discharge all patients are required to have clearly documented clinical criteria for discharge (CCD's) recorded in their notes to ensure patients receive ongoing care with minimal delay once medically optimised.
Directorate Bronze/Managers:
Responsible for ensuring the bed management policy is followed on a daily basis within their directorates. Escalating any concerns regarding bed management and admissions to the clinical site team.
Assistant Director of Operations: Responsible for:
Updating this policy in line with changing requirements.
Ensuring STAFFnet is provided with a copy of the Guidelines and policy.
Ward Matrons / Directorate Matrons:

Matrons are responsible for ensuring all ward staff are adhering to this policy. In addition matrons will maintain oversight of quality and safety issues that may impact the safe transfer of patients into, or between wards.
Control Room (Billericay):

Responsible for maintaining safe and effective bed management in accordance with this policy and for reporting any issues impacting bed management and admissions to the problems to the clinical site coordinator/manager.
Clinical Site Managers (CSM) / Coordinators:

Responsible for ensuring the smooth transfer of patients between departments and wards. Any immediate bed / capacity problems reported from the Emergency Department will be dealt with by the CSM in close liaison with the control room;
Beds will be allocated within 30 minutes of the request, and where this is not possible it is escalated to the Clinical Site Manager.
Records will be kept of the patients details for transfer (TeleTracking system).
Record will be kept of time bed requested / time bed allocated / where allocated (TeleTracking system).
Emergency admissions and escalation within (ED)
Emergency Department Inter Professional Standards
A number of Emergency Department (ED) Internal Professional Standards will apply to the pathway for patients.
Emergency ambulance arrivals will be accepted into ED within  minutes of arrival
Patients will be seen by a doctor within 60 minutes of arrival in the ED.
Any patient referred to a specialty team should be seen or transferred within  minutes of referral (see 2.1). This may be a transfer to SAU or AMU.
Following the completion of the clinical assessment the ED doctor will make a decision to admit or discharge within 2.5 hours.
The time taken to arrive in ED, receive treatment and leave the department will be no more than 4 hours.
All times of patient assessment and decisions should be documented in the patient's notes by medical staff and nursing staff.

It is the responsibility of the lead nurse in ED to monitor any time delays of potential breaches, ensuring the AMU staff are informed of the decision to admit and made aware of any potential breaches at three hours. If a delay is anticipated, the Clinical Site Manager will be informed by the lead ED nurse at 3 hours from arrival at the latest. This will allow time for a bed to be available. This action should be documented on the breach monitoring tool, and the nursing notes.

The Control Room/CSM are responsible for allocating all in-patient beds. Patients will be allocated in ‘time in ED department' order. Exception to these rules includes clinically unstable patients and those patients with a 12hour DTA, which are to be escalated to the ED consultant and Deputy / Director of Operations to agree exit plans.
If patients are still in ED after 4 hours the ED Manager will escalate any breaches to the capacity meetings/clinical site coordinator/Senior Manager on Call (SMoC) out of hours.
Out of hours, if patients are delayed in the ED over 4 hours, the Clinical Site Manager is informed, who will follow the bed escalation plan.
The Senior Nurse in ED will report all breaches to the capacity meetings.

12 Hour Breaches: If the patient waits over 12 hours, the same actions will be taken as in a 4 hour breach of standard, with the additional action that the Deputy / Director of Operations (in hours) or Senior Manager on Call (SMOC / Executive Director on call (out of hours)) will be informed. Further escalation will be undertaken by senior staff informed of the breach in accordance with the NHS England regional escalation policy.
Emergency 999 calls

If the patient on the way to ED is in cardiac arrest, ambulance staff will phone prior to arrival. The Trauma team will be alerted as appropriate prior to the arrival of patients with major/multiple injuries. The paediatric team will be contacted if a child in cardiac arrest is expected.
Other patients are triaged into clinical categories red/orange/yellow/green/blue by the Triage Nurse (Reference the Manchester triage system).

The Triage Nurse will ensure the time the patient arrives in the ED and the time the patient is handed over from ambulance crews is no longer than 15 minutes and the time is documented on the Triage form.
The Nurse in charge of ED is responsible for:
Ensuring effective assessment and handover systems are in place.
Ensuring transfers have occurred to and from the Acute Medical and Surgical units within  mins of the decision (subject to bed availability).
Ensuring ED capacity is available to support ambulance attendances.
Liaising with the Clinical Site Manager to ensure appropriate transfers have been made from ED.
Following the Trust escalation protocol the CSM to be informed for onward escalation to service managers and consultant staff should support be required when the target breaches cannot be resolved.

Ambulance control is informed of any delays. The duty officer should be informed and attend ED to assist in expediting delays (note: a HALO may be present). The Associate Director of Operations or the deputy will be called by the Clinical Site Managers to support service decision-making.
Escalation Protocol from ED (see Appendix 1)
Emergency Referrals from General Practitioners

General Practitioner (GP) admissions should be organised by telephoning switchboard at MSE asking for the on call Registrar/surgical navigator. Patients should be asked to attend ED bringing a referral letter. The patient may be directed to the Acute Medical Unit or Surgical Assessment Unit.
On arrival at the triage point in AMU/ED/SAU the on call doctor is informed that the patient has arrived. The doctor will then prioritise the patient according to clinical need and caseload.
All GP referrals will have a nursing assessment within 20 minutes of arrival.

If the GP has provided sufficient information the patient's notes must be requested by the ED receptionist to support clinical management and prevent delays in the assessment process. ED reception staff will record that a request has been made for notes (see Appendix 2 requesting medical records).
Self-referrals to the ED
All self-referrals will be triaged by the triage nurse.
Patients referred from ED to the on-call medical/surgical team

The ED Doctor will phone the on call medical or surgical navigator to discuss the case. Acute medical or surgical patients are transferred to the AMU or SAU for clinical assessment. Fractured Neck of Femur patients are reviewed by ED and following confirmation of a positive fracture are transferred straight to Castle Point ward, dedicated trauma bed within one hour. If there are no beds in the units or the patients are triaged as "resus" status they will remain in ED for review by the registrar.
Paediatric Referrals
Each site has different processes for the paediatric referrals.
Paediatric Escalation Protocol
When there is lack of availability of paediatric beds for emergency admissions via the Emergency Department, the paediatric escalation is followed.
Referrals to the Paediatric Rapid Access Clinics

This service is available for GPs who require a rapid assessment on a child by a senior Paediatrician. Some General Paediatric Clinic slots are reserved for such Rapid Access children. The children are usually seen in 2-3 weeks, but this cannot be guaranteed.
Referrals for the Neonatal Unit
Admissions to the Neonatal Unit will be in agreement with the Speciality Trainee or Consultant Paediatrician/Neonatologist on-call.
Decision to admit

It is the responsibility of consultant staff to make prompt decisions to admit, discharge or cancel the admission of patients. Decisions must be timely and documented in the patient's health record, with comprehensive use of both EDD's and CCD's for all inpatients.
Emergency Department 4 Hour Quality Standard

Doctors in ED will proactively work to a 2.5 hour decision time that leads to a 3 hour exit plan in order to achieve the 4 hour national 95% waiting time standard and maintain a safe patient pathway. In order to achieve this, patients will be seen within 60 minutes of arrival, with a decision to admit or discharge within 2.5 hours. (See the S.O.P for achieving the 4 hour National Standard).
Referrals to Speciality

The senior ED Doctor is responsible for timely referral within 2.5 hours to a speciality in order to facilitate a safe patient flow. Any patient accepted by a speciality but waiting review will be transferred to the appropriate assessment unit within the 3 hour exit plan.
Assessment wards and ward admissions
Basic Principles of Bed Management
The safe and effective management of patient flow is one of the most important functions within an acute hospital. These are the key principles of capacity management and patient flow:
Safety of patients will be maintained at all times with due consideration to risks from the emergency department to assessment areas, through to wards and safe discharge.
Emergency admissions take priority over elective admissions (with above exceptions).
All admissions and transfers are co-ordinated through the Billericay control room (local trust liaison will be via the clinical site manager).
Bed capacity will be created in a timely manner ensuring safety and performance is maintained.
Timely senior clinical decision making  hours a day.
Optimising patient placement – right patient, right place, right time.
Managing variance and/or surge.
Each directorate as far as possible will manage within its own bed stock.
No patient will have more than 2 transfers for non-clinical reasons and this will be monitored by the directorate matrons and clinical site managers.
The Trust will monitor the capacity of speciality bed use to guide future requirements.
Acute Medical Unit (AMU)

The acute medical unit is able to care for monitored and close observation adult patients with a stay of up to 24 hours. No child under 16 years should be sent to the AMU. Patients will have a 2 hourly review and the average length of stay in the AMU will behours (see the AMU Operational Policy).

If the ED reception staff have not already been given details of patients due for admission they must now order patients' notes to support the clinical management of the patients. A record should be made in the patient's notes of the date and time a request was made and the time notes were received.
To maintain safe patient flow through the pathway the aim is to have 5 empty beds in AMU at all times

In order to access a speciality bed, the Doctor will request a bed via TeleTracking according to the patient's speciality. The clinical site manager in liaison with the directorate daily leads will support the creation of capacity to meet this demand.

In exceptional circumstances when there are no available medical beds, in order to make urgent capacity for emergency medical admissions, patients will be transferred from a specialty medical ward to a non-specialty ward for a non-clinical reason. The patient will remain under the original medical consultant, and discharge planning will continue with the MDT of the accepting ward. These are classed as outliers as above.
Please refer to Appendix 1 Medicine Directorate Admissions SoP for further information.
The Surgical Assessment Unit (SAU)

This unit provides assessment for surgical emergency adult patients and is segregated into single sex areas. No child under  years should be sent to the SAU. Surgical ward rounds occur at 8am Monday to Friday. At weekends the on- call Registrar undertakes a ward round each morning.
To maintain safe patient flow through the pathway the aim is to have 3 empty beds in SAU at all times.
Identification of Patients Suitable to Transfer from a Speciality Bed

It is the responsibility of medical and nursing staff of each ward to identify patients daily who are suitable for transfer to other wards, according to criteria agreed between ward manager and consultants.

At the morning white board meeting, a plan of care is to be discussed for each patient. Discharges are to be prioritised and planned into the discharge lounge before 11.00am, Monday to Friday. Discharges for the following day are also planned with section 5 notifications sent, and TTA s written.
Monitoring of Patient Transfers

Each patient move will be identified as a clinical or a non-clinical transfer, according to criteria agreed between ward managers and consultants and recorded within the TeleTracking system. No patient will have more than 2 ward transfers for non- clinical reasons. The details of patient transfers will be recorded through the TeleTracking system.
Exceptions to the Standard procedure (Medical Patients)

The success of the admission system is highly dependent on creating a steady flow of patients through AMU and the wards. Speciality beds need to be made available by prompt discharges. Where there are demands for speciality beds exceeding the existing capacity, patients are identified for transfer from that ward to another medical ward. Patients transferred to an alternative wards will remain the responsibility of the transferring ward consultant and junior Doctors.

Within working hours, when insufficient patients have been identified to provide capacity required for new admissions from AMU, matrons and clinical site managers will assist in identifying patients deemed appropriate for transfer, by discussing with the available senior medical staff and nursing staff.
Escalation / exception to the Standard Procedure

Every effort should be made to avoid direct admission to a non-speciality medical bed. When there are no available beds in that speciality ward, the bed managers will contact the clinical site manager (CSM), who will liaise with the available medical and nursing staff to discuss safe to transfer patients from that speciality area to an alternative non speciality bed from the list of patients identified.

If there are no patients identified, the nurse in charge will discuss all patients on the ward with a decision making Doctor in order to either identify patients or agree for the new admission to be cared for in an alternative ward but remain under the care of the speciality consultant.

Between 17.00 and 08.00am when there are no senior decision making Doctors on each ward, the control centre, in liaison with the CSM, will make decisions on the admission of each patient into speciality wards, taking into account the following considerations:
No patient will be moved more than twice for a non-clinical reason.
Where possible, avoid moving any patient between 23:00 and 07:30.
Any mover will be discussed with the nurse in charge of the ward.
Where possible, avoid moving confused patients.

(Surgical wards will currently accommodate safe for transfer patients, following discussion with the lead manager for surgical beds for the day, and patients will remain under their original physician/buddy ward.

A patient who, as a result of a failure of correct patient flow, will be allocated to the consultant who was the on-call physician at the time of transfer. The night clinical site manager will be responsible for providing the duty consultant with a list of these patients on AMU before 0830hrs.
Admission arrangements for patient with a Learning Disability

If the patient for admission has a learning disability which is registered with their GP, then a MEDWAY alert will flag on admission to the hospital as a LEARN as soon as the patient is booked into the system. If there is currently no MEDWAY flag, a form is completed and sent to the adult safeguarding team who can add the alert.

Any patient with LD who requires admission will be identified to the Clinical Site manager / control room by the requesting area to ensure admission to the most clinically appropriate ward. The clinical or specialist need of the patient will always take priority, for example patients requiring critical care will be admitted to critical care.

The clinical site manager / control room will consider the need for the LD patient to be supported during admission. In some cases the carer may wish to stay with the patient and in these cases every effort must be made to try and transfer the patient to a side room.

The admitting ward will be informed of the LD diagnosis and any identified or enhanced needs including specialist equipment, supervision requirements and any other reasonable adjustments that have been identified.
Emergency Admissions from OPD Clinics

Consultant staff wishing to arrange an admission directly from an outpatient clinic should contact the appropriate on-call team prior to arranging transfer to a ward through teletracking, which will be picked up by the CSM. If urgent then a phone call should be made to the CSM to make the move a priority.
If there are no beds available immediately the patient may, if medically unfit, be accommodated on the ambulatory care unit or an assessment areas with prior arrangement with the acute consultant.
Admission criteria to inpatient beds

On admission to an inpatient ward the receiving nurse will ensure a safe clinical handover is given, with medical notes, and the patient's property is checked in at handover, along with the details of carers or relatives informed, and medication. The following is required for all inpatient admissions:
A transfer form be completed and filed in the notes.
Medway will be updated with transfer details.

Notes will be tracked on the notes tracker within Medway (if medical notes are not available, the ward clerk will set up a temporary set, or OOH nurse in charge contacts medical records where a temporary set will be provided).

All patients requiring an inpatient admission will be allocated a bed via the TeleTracking system. Any issues associated with this process will be escalated via the hospital clinical site coordinator.
General Medicine (Bed Allocation)
Please refer to the Medicine Directorate Admissions Procedure for further detailed information regarding medicine wards admission.
General Surgery (Bed Allocation)
The Department of Surgery accept both elective and emergency admissions. Wherever possible, all patients should be allocated to the appropriate specialty ward.
Obstetrics and gynaecology
The Department of Gynae accept emergency admissions. All patients should be allocated to the correct ward where they can be reviewed by the correct speciality.
Early discharge should be identified in liaison with the Consultant on-call.
Any pregnant women to be transferred to maternity wards.
Admissions should be considered to surgical beds.
Trauma and Orthopaedic Surgery
Each hospital accepts both elective and emergency admissions. Where possible, all patients should be allocated to the appropriate speciality ward.
Ophthalmology Inpatient and Day Case Admissions

There are 0 inpatient beds in the Ophthalmology unit. In the event of a patient requiring an overnight stay the patient will be admitted to a surgical bed. This happens approximately 4 times in a year and will be cared for by the on call Ophthalmology team.
Day Surgery Unit

Not all patients (i.e. those undergoing local anaesthetic) require 1st (post-operative recovery) or 2nd stage recovery. The unit has two sets of admissions per day (morning and lunchtime), and admits patients for:
Surgery within the Day Stay Theatres.
Surgery within Main Theatres.
Patients from Orthopaedics, Gynaecology, General Surgery, ENT, Oral, Urology and Maxiollo/Facial are booked for surgery within the day surgery theatres.

When the decision to admit as a day stay is reached, the TCI card is sent to the pre- assessment office within day stay. Patients are then entered onto the waiting list. Patients are either pre-assessed by post or brought in to a pre-assessment clinic. Once it has been agreed that the patient is suitable for day surgery the unit will place the patient onto a theatre list and they will be admitted (through the Teletracking system).
For all other specialities, a TCI card is sent to the relevant booking clerk. The patient is placed onto the waiting list. Patients are then booked for the theatre session.

The Day Surgery unit checks the intended admissions via the TCI list. On the day prior to surgery the admission list is checked against the operating theatre list to confirm the admissions and issued to the Billericay control centre for entry into the TeleTracking system.
Day surgery Patients Requiring an Inpatient Bed
Some patients booked as day cases will require an in-patient bed due to post- operative problems. All requests for beds must be directed through the TeleTracking system.

If a patient is deemed unsuitable for day surgery pre-operatively, the lead manager for surgery and the clinical site coordinator / control room are informed immediately so that the decision to continue with the procedure can be considered in conjunction with the current booked elective workload.
DSSA (delivering same sex accommodation)
Delivering Same Sex Accommodation (DSSA)
NHS organisations are expected to deliver same sex accommodation, except where it is in the overall best interests of the patient, or reflects their personal choice.
Breaches of policy
There are some circumstances where mixing can be justified. These are few and are mainly confined to patients who need highly specialised care, such as that delivered in critical care units.
Acceptable justification – (i.e. not a breach)
In the event of a life-threatening emergency, either on admission or due to a sudden deterioration in a patient's condition.
Where a critically ill patient requires constant one-to-one nursing care, e.g. in ICU.

Where a nurse must be physically present in the room/bay at all times (the nurse may have responsibility for more than one patient (e.g. level 2 care). This would be unacceptable if staff shortages or skill mix were the rationale.
Where a short period of close patient observation is needed e.g. immediate post-anaesthetic recovery, or where there is a high risk of adverse drug reactions.
On the joint admission of couples or family groups.
Unacceptable justification – (i.e. a breach) Placing a patient in mixed-sex accommodation for:
The convenience of medical, nursing or other staff, or from a desire to group patients within a clinical specialty.
Because of a shortage of staff or poor skill mix.
Because of restrictions imposed by old or difficult estate because of a shortage of beds.
Because of predictable fluctuations in activity or seasonal pressures.
Because of a predictable non-clinical incident e.g. a ward closure.
Whilst waiting for assessment, treatment or a clinical decision.
Placing a patient in mixed-sex accommodation for regular but not constant observation.

It is not acceptable to mix sexes purely on the basis of clinical specialism. For instance, in a stroke unit, it may be acceptable to mix patients immediately following admission (life-threatening emergency, and in need of one-to-one nursing), but not to maintain mixing throughout the rehabilitation phase, simply on the basis that it is easier for staff, or because there are not enough people with the necessary skills.
DSSA in extreme operational emergencies

There will be a very small set of circumstances where mixing is acceptable as an emergency response to extreme operational emergencies. This is limited to unpredictable events such as major clinical incidents e.g. a multiple road traffic accident or natural disaster, and major non-clinical incidents such as fire or flood requiring immediate evacuation of buildings.

Delivering Same Sex Accommodation (DSSA) principles are based on every patient having the right to receive high quality care that is safe, effective and respects their privacy and dignity. This means that patients should be cared for in a ward or bay which does not have patients of the opposite sex being treated within it. The area should have a full height screen. The patients should have access to co-located toilet and bathroom facilities which do not require them to pass patients of the opposite sex in order to access them.
Decision to mix – Clinical Justification
There are occasions when a decision to mix will need to be made. This is usually based on clinical need and in order to ensure safety for the patient.
The below process is to be considered:
Interim measure for emergencies into AMU for overnight admission only. Max of  hours, and should be reversed by 10.00 the following morning
Critical care

The Adult Critical Care unit provides a comprehensive service for level 3 patients. Full guidelines for admission and discharge to Critical Care are detailed in the Essex Network Common Admission / Discharge Protocol For Critical Care. The policy is based on the recommendations made in the document 'Guidelines on admission to and discharge from Intensive Care and High Dependency units', DOH, March 1996 (NHS Executive).
Patients will be admitted if they fulfil both of the following criteria;

a) Patients who require advanced respiratory support alone i.e. mechanical ventilatory support via an endotracheal tube excluding mask CPAP and non-invasive ventilation. (BiPAP via facemask is a level 2 intervention).
b) Patients who require support of two or more organ systems.
Referring a Patient to the Critical Care Unit:

Referral of a patient for admission to critical care should be on a consultant to consultant basis as per national guidelines (and also as stated in NICE Clinical Guideline 50: Acutely ill patients in hospital 2007).

In an emergency, the critical care consultant may accept a referral from the referring consultant and admit the patient directly to the unit. Patients on the unit remain under the care of the referring consultant who should review them regularly. The final decision regarding admission rests with the duty critical care consultant.
Critical Care Emergency Admissions:
These take precedence over all elective admissions. Documented evidence in the medical notes will show that an assessment for admission to Critical Care has taken place by the referring team.
Critical Care Elective Admissions:

The patient's consultant or his/her delegate will inform the Critical Care Consultant or SpR about the admission. These elective admissions should be entered on the board available for this purpose on the critical care unit. Surgery must not be started until the availability of a Critical Care bed has been confirmed on the day of surgery by a member of the surgical team.

If an elective patient has already been admitted to hospital then their booked bed may be “closed” to outside admissions. In the event of more than one booked admission and insufficient available beds to accommodate all the cases, priority will go to the patients in the order that they are booked on the Critical Care board. If this is not acceptable to the other teams, clinical need will be discussed between the Surgical Consultants involved. Critical Care staff will not mediate.
Elective surgical patients booked for level 3 care will usually be admitted only if there are >2 level 3 beds free at the time of their proposed surgery.
Critical Care Children:

Children are accepted for resuscitation/stabilisation and then transfer as recommended by the National Co-ordinating Group on Paediatric Intensive Care (Paediatric Intensive Care; A Framework for the Future - Department of Health Infants are no longer admitted to the Critical Care unit when they are the responsibility of paediatrics and the neonatal unit.
Plasmapheresis:
Patients are not admitted for plasmapheresis (but this may be provided for existing level 3 patients who are already patients on critical care).
Critical Care Admissions from Other Trusts:

When Critical Care is not full, patients can be accepted from other hospitals. Patients are accepted with the agreement that the referring hospital will take the patient back once space becomes available in their Critical Care Unit (or to the first available ward bed if Critical Care is no longer required). Patients should be referred to the Critical Care Consultant and also to the on-call consultant for the referring specialty.

As Critical Care beds are scarce, they should be considered a Network-wide resource and hence patients no longer requiring Critical Care should be the priority patients to receive ward beds as they become available.
When Critical Care is Full:

If Critical Care is full (see Bed Management section below) further elective admissions must be cancelled and the booked patient's Consultant (or delegate) and the anaesthetist informed. As stated above, surgery should never commence without confirmation that a bed is available.

If a patient in the hospital (Ward or Accident and Emergency) requires a Critical Care bed and the Unit is full, the ICU Consultant should be contacted and arrangements to transfer a patient to another hospital should be made as per the Essex Network Transfer Policy.

If the referring team is aware that all Critical Care beds are occupied, they must continue to seek Critical Care assessment. In this way seriously ill patients will have the opportunity to receive the most appropriate care in a timely fashion.
Critical Care Bed Management
Under normal circumstances up to  level 3 beds should be available on Critical Care.
One bed will be reserved for in-house arrests. One bed should be kept for patients under review by the outreach service as these have a high risk of requiring Critical Care admission.

This means that if 8 or more beds are occupied (or if the number of occupied beds plus planned elective admissions equals 8 or more) transfers/repatriations from outside will not be accepted and EBS will be informed that the unit is full. If there are less than 8 occupied beds the available beds should be declared to EBS.

In the week prior to the on call for the vascular rota weekend (Friday evening through to Monday morning closely followed by Tuesday evening to Wednesday morning) repatriations/transfers in, should not normally be accepted. It is important to note that if the weekend includes a bank holiday Monday the on-call period would be even longer as it would include Friday evening + all day Saturday, Sunday AND Monday + Tuesday evening and Wednesday Morning.
When accepting a transfer (not repatriation) from another ITU (because they are full), check:
a) MRSA status
b) Details of other patients on that unit

It is up to the accepting unit to decide which patient they will take and the most appropriate/safest transfer is not always the one suggested by the referring unit. Where possible, avoid accepting those patients known to have MRSA. In addition the referring unit also has to contact an appropriate medical or surgical team at Southend to formally accept the patient.
Discharge from Critical Care Level 3 Bed:
Daily assessment must be made of the patient's progress. Patients should be discharged when any of the following applies:
a) The patient no longer requires advanced respiratory support via an endotracheal tube/tracheostomy or support of two or more organ systems.
b) The patient is no longer expected to benefit from the treatment available, or
c) When Critical Care is full and it is necessary to admit another patient.

All decisions to discharge a patient will be made at Consultant level. A discharge summary must be completed by the duty anaesthetist using the pre-printed forms which should be placed in the notes. The Patient's Consultant or delegate (or the on-call team out-of-hours) must then be informed of the discharge. There is also space to record this on the form.
Exclusion from Critical Care:
Patients may not be admitted to Critical Care if:
a) They do not fulfil the admission criteria above.
b) The patient has an irreversible current illness with a complication that would not be expected to benefit from further intervention.
c) A competent patient has previously expressed a wish not to be admitted.
d) The patient requires tertiary specialist skills not available on site, the patient is fit for transfer and a specialist bed is available.
e) The unit is already full, the patient is fit for transfer and a bed is available elsewhere.
f) The patient currently requires higher provision of nursing attention due solely to challenging behaviour.
g) The patient requires single organ support (excluding advanced respiratory support).
h) The patient only requires level 2 care.

Patients in categories (g) and (h) will not normally be considered for admission to critical care. If there are occasions where demand for level 3 care is reduced (and there are more than 2 available beds) it MAY be possible to consider admission. Such patients will be discharged if a level 3 patient subsequently requires admission.
Requesting a Surgical / Medical Bed for Critical Care Unit Discharges:

All requests for beds will go via the Teletracking system with notification to the clinical site coordinator to support the prioritisation of bed requests (as appropriate in accordance with above principles).
The Critical Care Unit should inform the clinical site coordinator if there are:
a) Patients to be discharged that day and an approximate time and level of acuity.
b) Patients that will be discharged in the event of an emergency admission, and
c) Any patients that are likely to be discharged the following day and level of acuity.
If there are no beds available immediately in surgery/medicine, the control room will check all ward discharges to assess for potential bed availability.

If no surgical/medical bed has been identified for critical care, then the clinical site coordinator and/or Critical Care will contact the designated person in medicine/surgery responsible for beds on that particular day, and follow the escalation procedure.
At weekends should there be problems with obtaining surgical/medical beds for the Critical Care Unit pressures are to be escalated to the senior manager/executive on call to support resolution.
Follow-up Care of Patients with Tracheostomies:

Patients with tracheostomies will initially be discharged with (and accompanied by) a member of the critical care outreach/nursing team who will ensure that a safe handover to the ward nurses takes place. Subsequently the outreach team will continue to provide support according to clinical need.

Patients will be discharged from Critical Care to designated wards (surgical patients to the Surgical HDU, Medical patients to Westcliff, Rochford/ARCU). Elizabeth Loury may be used when requested by an ENT Consultant.
Patients may also be discharged to the main theatre post-operative ward (which is the escalation area if critical care is full).
In the event of a major tracheostomy problem, the cardiac arrest team and the critical care registrar should be summoned.
Critical Care Tertiary/Clinical Transfers:

When a patient needs admission to a level 3 bed and they cannot be accommodated at Southend as their clinical condition requires specialist care (e.g. neurosurgical or cardiothoracic) the patient will require transfer to a tertiary hospital. The arrangements must be made via the Emergency Bed Service (EBS) by the consultant in charge and the nearest tertiary centre with an available bed identified. Travel arrangements will be made by the critical care clinician and the clinical site lead.

The doctor in charge of the patient will ring the on-call registrar at the allocated Hospital and give all the clinical details. The patient will be stabilised prior to transfer, be accompanied by a Doctor and also by a Nurse, Paramedic, or Operating Department Assistant/Practitioner (ODA/P). Copies of the particular/relevant record should be sent with the patient at the time of transfer. Under no circumstances should original records be sent.

The Ambulance Service arranges transport. If a police escort is required, it will be arranged by Ambulance control. Helicopter transfers are hazardous with limited access and monitoring has failed. We would not use this mode of transfer if at all possible.
The accompanying Doctor must ensure that a Transfer Form containing the patient's essential medical information is fully completed. The copies of these forms must be sent to the designated areas: -

Non-clinical Transfers (when the Critical Care Unit is full):
Level 3 critical beds at Southend are closed to further admission when all staffed beds are full.

The decision to close the unit for further admissions is made jointly by the nurse in charge and the duty Anaesthetist. The EBS contacts the unit at regular intervals throughout the day and they will be informed of the closure of the unit.

When an in-patient needs admission to a level 3 bed and cannot be accommodated at Southend, the Critical Care clinician will arrange the transfer via the EBS. Patients who are transferred for non-clinical reasons must, as far as possible, be transferred to those hospitals within the local transfer group.
Southend Hospital's Transfer Group is (telephone numbers available via switchboard):

Where transfers do take place outside the group the responsible consultant must ensure the transfer is agreed with the responsible consultant at the receiving hospital.
Paediatric elective admissions
All children requiring a planned admission will have a TCI card generated by a Registrar or Consultant for their name to go onto the waiting list.
When a child is to be admitted, the bed is booked through Neptune Unit clerk. All children and their parents should be notified by letter to come directly to Neptune Unit on the appointed day.
Neonatal Unit:

Admissions to the Neonatal Unit will be in agreement with the Registrar or Consultant Paediatrician/Neonatologist on-call. However, if a baby requires admission urgently from either the Delivery Suite or Post-natal wards at the request of the midwife or nurse, no baby will be refused admission.
Discharge lounge

The Discharge Lounge allows the transfer of patients waiting to go home in order to free acute hospital beds. It accommodates up to  patients at any one time, and the opening hours are between 08.00 and 20.00 hours. Patients for discharge on the day should be transferred before 11.00am. Patients are to be transferred from the ward to the discharge lounge, not discharged off the Medway system.

Patients transferred to the lounge should have their TeleTracking badge ‘dropped' on transfer to the lounge to generate a bed cleaning request. Patients will be discharged from Medway once they leave the discharge lounge.
Patient's clinical notes are to always accompany patients to the discharge lounge.
Infection control
These guidelines have been prepared to minimise the risk to other patients or staff when a patient that is a potential infection risk is admitted, transferred or discharged within the hospital.

All patients with an Alert on Medway for MRSA to risk assessed for the need for isolation. They must be swabbed on arrival to the ward in order to ascertain their current status. The ward to advise the Infection Control department of the patient's admission.
All patients with an Alert on Medway for C diff /C diff carrier – if symptomatic with type 5-7 stools must be isolated and stool sample obtained.

All patients from a nursing home, rest home, and other institutions such as prisons to be nursed in a side room and swabbed to ascertain their status, until their MRSA status is known, then advice from Infection Control should be taken.
All repatriations/transfers from other hospitals (Including transfers from abroad) must be isolated on admission and screened for MRSA, CPO and MDRA.
Any patient with diarrhoea or vomiting or highly suspicious of C diff, must be nursed in a side room and a stool specimen obtained in order to ascertain infectivity.

Any patient with a known blood-borne virus infection may generally be nursed in an open ward, unless actively bleeding. However the Infection Control department needs to be informed of the patient's admission so that ward staff can be informed of the correct procedures when dealing with the patient.

Any patient with an infestation, i.e. scabies, lice, fleas, should be admitted into a side room until effective therapy has been administered. Then the room must be cleaned thoroughly before admission of another patient. In the case of fleas/bed bugs the room may need to be fumigated before another patient is admitted into it.
Any patient with confirmed pulmonary tuberculosis to be nursed in a side room on Westcliff Ward with the doors kept shut.
If Influenza is suspected, isolate the patient in a side room - door shut, take viral swabs and ensure Tamiflu is prescribed.

Any patient admitted with Meningococcal meningitis, Haemophilus meningitis to be nursed in a side room for the first 24 hours of treatment. Infection Control to be notified of admission, as all 'kissing contacts' need to be traced by PHE.
There are many other infectious illnesses requiring the patient to be nursed in a side room. A detailed list of these can be found in the Isolation Policy IC019.
When no side rooms are available, the Infection Control Team must be contacted to provide advice.
Between the hours of 08.00 and 16.30 hours the Infection Control Team can be contacted for related advice and guidance.

Appendix 2: Procedure for requesting medical records for emergency admissions

It is Trust policy to get patient records to the point of patient care as quickly as possible. This ensures appropriate treatment and helps us to comply with Clinical Governance. This document sets out a clear procedure, identifying the individual who is responsible for specific aspects of the service.
Responsibilities of each Department/individual are outlined as follows:- Emergency Department / Acute Medical Units / Acute Surgical Unit

At the point of transfer to an Acute Assessment unit or a decision to admit directly to a ward from the ED, it is the responsibility of the receptionist / ward clerk to request medical records. These will be delivered according to the priority of clinical need.
Over the 24 hour period, a list is faxed to Medical Records to request notes.
All notes must be tracked in on Medway.
Medical Records Library
Requests received in the Library from ED or AMU and SAU are prioritised, and after retrieval, the notes will be delivered by the Medical Records Staff to ED / Assessment units.
All Wards
Emergency admissions to the wards from ED or assessment units should be accompanied by their medical records.

It is the responsibility of the ward clerk/ward manager to ensure that patients arriving without notes have these requested from Medical Records immediately. This can be done by telephoning ext 2304/2257.
All notes must be tracked in on Medway

When patients are discharged it is the responsibility of all clerical staff to ensure that patient records are returned to the Medical Records Library as soon as possible, in order that they can be available for any future visits.
Appendix 3: SoP to support the 4 hour emergency standard

This standard operating procedure (SOP) will support the Trust-wide 4 hour Emergency Standard. This SOP outlines the required actions for specific staff to ensure effective patient flow throughout the Trust. It also sets out the escalation procedures to maintain patient flow which are summarised within the Appendix 2 flowchart.
Note: Clinical exception breaches do not fall into this escalation process
The safe and effective management of patient flow is one of the most important functions within an acute hospital. There are 4 key activities of capacity management and patient flow:
Creating capacity in a timely manner.
Timely Senior Clinical Decision Making.
Optimising patient placement – right patient right place right time.
Managing variance or surge.
All beds available for use are detailed on TeleTracking which required staff have access to real-time.

Focussed bed capacity meetings will occur Monday to Friday each day at 08:45, 12.00 and 15.00 hours with a further on call / handover meeting taking place at 17:00. The meeting will be led by the clinical site manager and supported by each of the designated directorate manager/matron of the day.

The control room will display a TeleTracking bed state at each meeting to provide an overview of all available capacity and demand. This process will prioritise the actions needed by each directorate bronze/manager and matron of the day, along with the clinical site manager to address capacity and demand issues and to facilitate flow within the hospital.

Monday to Friday 08.30 to 17.00 hours – Medicine, Surgery, Women & Children's, Diagnostic & Therapeutic and MSK directorates will identify, on a rota basis, a manager who is responsible for patient flow in their areas and who will work closely with the clinical site coordinator. They must attend bed capacity meetings held in the control room (see section 10.1 below) and their contact details must be made aware.

Their role is to be the first point of contact (in hours) for patient flow issues within their own directorates. The daily bronze/manager will identify the root cause of any issues raised and take a proactive approach to solving any problems. The directorate bronze/matron will also work with the relevant matron to ensure potential capacity problems are anticipated throughout their wards during their shift and ensure their wards do not delay any patient requiring a bed. Bed capacity must be anticipated and planned in advance throughout the day. Actions necessary to improve bed flow will be agreed at each meeting with a named individual in that directorate to take the action forward. It will be checked at the follow up meeting.

There will be either a clinical site manager (CSM) or a clinical site coordinator (CSC) on site at all times. They will be supported further team members based within the Billericay control centre. They are responsibility during the  hour period for allocation of beds to TeleTracking requests and escalation/support of any issues that may affect safe patient flow to be effectively managed in accordance with the following performance targets:
A&E 4 hour emergency standard.
Elective patient access targets e.g.  week RTT; 6 week diagnostic; 28 day readmission; cancer targets.
ICU delayed discharge – Target is to transfer within 10 hours.
Patients will be allocated to a bed within 30 minutes of the request.
Patients will be repatriated from other hospitals to Southend within  hours of notification (subject to side room availability).
Infection prevention and appropriate use of side rooms.
Compliance with same sex accommodation guidance

Regularly review the ED TeleTracking requests and support the ED Nurse in Charge (NIC) to ensure that all requests for patient movement should happen within  minutes.
Attend ED, AMU and SAU immediately at the start of the shift and assess the capacity and flow through the ED to the wards and assessment units.
Liaise with the ED Nurse in Charge and ensure all patients have an exit plan and are on track to transfer at 3 hours.

Visit priority areas and provide practical support to create capacity. When necessary this may include, although not exhaustive, making beds, ensuring ward processes are in place and to facilitate a patient transfer/discharge which may include collecting TTA medication.

what alternative action is needed.

Proactively manage unplanned issues and site specific problems, provide advice and support.

Ensure a list of all outlying patients from medicine into surgery is provided to the appropriate medical staff to enable a timely clinical review.

Liaise with the lead Nurse / Doctor in ED to discuss any anticipated issues that may affect patient flow, and escalate as per flow chart
Clinical Site Managers Out of hours:
In addition to the above, clinical site managers out of hours will ensure that they provide support to the whole hospital site.
Lead on operational bed issues and be based in ED and the acute admitting units in order to maintain safe emergency patient flow.
Provide a clinical support role to all wards and departments liaising with on call medics and hospital out of hours team (HOOH).

In liaising with the duty matron, assess all staffing levels throughout the Trust and escalate short notice sickness, maintaining safe levels of staff for patient care and flow of admissions to senior managers on call (SMoC).
Arrange short notice essential transport as per transport protocol, ensuring approval from the CCG and the PTS provider framework is followed.

The ED Nurse in Charge will:
Supervise all activity in ED for the shift period.
Proactively manage ED patient flow in each area in the ED, deploying staff across areas accordingly.
Ensure ambulances are not delayed past 15 min handover period.
Ensure each patient pathway is progressing in order to meet the DTA time of
2.5 hours and the 3 hour exit time from ED.
ED Majors Co-ordinator:

The Majors Co-ordinator will work proactively with the major's medical team to ensure each patient has an exit plan from ED in place at 2.5 hours. If there is no plan and the co- ordinator anticipates a delay, they must start stage 1 escalation to ED Nurse in Charge.

Where the ED department is experiencing surge and a decision is taken by the ED Nurse in Charge that they are clinically required in trauma or resus, the ED Majors Co-ordinator will take over full responsibility for the role of the ED Nurse in charge.
Stage one escalation:

There is a delay in DTA at 2.5 hours, which may impact the 3 hour exit plan: the nurse in charge must discuss the plans with the medical team and take appropriate action to bring the pathway back on track for a 3 hour exit plan. This may involve contacting speciality teams, contacting the lead nurse in AMU or re-assessing the patient clinically.
Stage two escalation:

If the nurse in charge is unable to guarantee a 3 hour exit plan, escalation is made to the clinical site coordinator with appropriate details of any issues. The site lead will assess the situation and liaise with the senior Doctor in the ED. They will then contact speciality teams, or go direct to speciality managers if they feel it appropriate to escalate concerns/confirm plans.
Stage three escalation:

Where the clinical site coordinator is unable to resolve patient pathway delays at 2.5 hours, or if there is no progression of a plan to resolution by 3 hours, or for those patients who are at their breach time +4 hours, the site lead will escalate to:

This decision will depend on whether there is still time to prevent the breach with some speciality input, or whether further escalation to the appropriate directorate lead is required.

8. Escalation and on-call arrangements roles

Senior Manager On-Call (SMOC): will be on call out of hours (17.00 – 08:30 weekdays and a  hour period at weekends and bank holidays. Management of the SMOC rota is managed by the Deputy Director of operations.

The SMOC must be contactable at all times via their mobile telephone. It is the responsibility of the SMOC to ensure that switchboard has their contact details. At all times during the course of their period of on call, individuals must be available to attend the Trust site within 1 hour. Should an individual reside outside of the  minutes travelling time, they must make provision to remain on site, which might necessitate arranging for an overnight on call room to be available.

This SOP recommends that where possible within working practice, the SMOC will attend site Mon – Fri to be present for the 17:00 capacity meeting handover, the clinical/medical handovers and for a minimum ofhours if covering a weekend day. This remains subject to pressures being experienced and an reduced/extended period may be required.

The SMOC will attend the 15.00 (when available) and 17:00 (required) bed capacity meeting and liaise with the clinical site coordinator, duty matron and the ED Nurse in Charge to agree a safe plan for the night. Any issues should be discussed with the executive on-call at this point.

The SMOC will not leave the hospital site until the patient flow situation and the hospital site is stable, with no anticipated problems. They will be sure of the plan for the night and communicate this plan to the executive on call.
The SMOC will contact the clinical site coordinator at 22.00 (when off site) to ensure that the hospital site is still safe.

Escalation will be made from the CSC to the SMOC for any serious issue that the SMOC can assist with (see escalation above point 5). If a problem is escalated to the SMOC, they will attend the hospital site if they feel the problem cannot be resolved within 15 mins over the telephone. (see flowchart).
The SMOC will hand over any night issues to the clinical site operations team the following day, at the weekend/bank holidays ensuring the incoming SMOC is fully informed of any ongoing issues.

On call Executive Director / Directors On-Call: The on-call Executive Director will attend the 15.00 (when available) and the 17:00 (required) bed capacity meetings and following discussions with the SMOC will be confident of the plans for the night.
